p: The methanol extract of L. inermis leaves had significant activity against all tested bacteria. Among the tested strains, S. aureus ATCC 25923, MRSA ATCC®43300TM, E. coli ATCC 25922, E. coli, and Streptococcus pyogenes isolates were the most susceptible, with a zone of inhibition comparable to cefoxitin and penicillin at all tested concentrations. This finding supports the work of Manivannan et al. [ 17], Kannahi et al. [ 18], and Badoni et al. [ 19]. ß-asarones, the active constituents found in the leaves, roots, and rhizomes of the L. inermis, were responsible for all antimicrobial activities [ 20].
